CreditLine: Gift of Mrs. John Russell Pope, 1943
Description:
This intricate locket, with scenes inside and out, was probably used as a "paternoster", an aid to prayer similar to a rosary.  The scenes on the inside are executed in colorful enamel.  On the left, Christ is greeted as he enters Jerusalem on a donkey.  On the right, the risen Christ invites the "doubting" apostle Thomas to affirm his resurrection by touching his wound.

On the exterior (not visible) are two scenes executed in brown wax protected under rock crystal: the Virgin lamenting Christ's death, and a battered Christ shown to the people.
Dimensions:
1 7/16 in. (3.65 cm) (diam.);
locket open: 2 1/4 x 3 x 3/8 in. (5.76 x 7.58 x 1 cm)

Exhibitions.Textblock: Jewelry - Ancient to Modern. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1979-1980.

Medium: basse-taille enamel on silver, wax, rock crystal, with gilded silver mount

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Second Floor: Collector's Study

Provenance: Collections of Passavant; Spitzer Sale, Paris, 1893, lot 1787; Mrs. John Russell Pope [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, 1943, by gift.
Title: Locket with Christ's Entry into Jerusalem and Doubting Thomas
